@LunchtimeLiveNT @ciarakellydoc @CAugustenborg @NewstalkFM A good way to grab people's attention about climate change

6. Nutrition can also have an impact on brain function. Our brains use lots of energy so we need to eat enough calories to keep it working well, and our nutritional status can affect how our brain cells talk to each other and protect themselves from damage. #WorldFoodDay

5. Older people with malnutrition are likely to visit the GP more often and they need to stay in hospital more frequently and for longer compared to well nourished people of the same age who have similar diagnoses #WorldFoodDay @SimonHarrisTD

4. The annual cost of malnutrition and the diseases associated with it is estimated to be 1.5 billion euro, representing over 10% of the total annual health and social care budget. #WorldFoodDay @SimonHarrisTD

3. Of the 3 million people in the UK at risk, nearly half are over the age of 65 & if we assume that the prevalence of malnutrition in the UK is similar to the prevalence in Ireland, as many as 70,000 Irish people aged 65 may be at risk of malnourishment #WorldFoodDay

2. We do not have accurate figures for malnutrition among older Irish adults, but a recent UK report suggests that between 20-60% of people admitted to geriatric wards in the UK are at risk of malnutrition #WorldFoodDay

1. In a @tcddublin study we conducted with 100 adults in Ireland with an average of 75 we found that 6.3% were malnourished and 23.1% were at risk for malnourishment #WorldFoodDay Anyone can become malnourished, but it is a particularly big problem among older people. https://t.co/G6Mm2GUt4t

@dingding_peng @statsepi If our public health policies & personal choices focused on prevention & healthy life choices the average age of death would probably increase (not indefinitely) but with less stress on healthcare we could possibly sustain that economically (I'm not a health economist though)

@dingding_peng @statsepi many chronic health conditions in later life are preventable We could live in better health until we die through something more acute my parents lived till late 80s, my mother a slow death from dementia my father a sudden death from myocardial infarction - I know which I'd prefer

Fab morning for a tour of the salt marsh. Really interesting talk from North Bull Island Nature Reserve https://t.co/tWuPytmsqm

@joanmckennaTV @nolansclontarf Thanks Joni - It turns out Woodies in Coolock sell reasonably priced wellies - they open at 10am so just waiting to call to see if they have my size in stock, Nolans don't open on Sunday btw
@johndodwyer @NWCI as a species we have indeed taken some wrong turns - I enjoyed this twitter conversation but I must sign off now - I need to find wellies for a salt marsh walk this morning

I'm going on a guided tour of the Salt Marsh Ecology on the North Bull Island Nature Reserve at 11am - I have waterproof gear but it turns out my waterproof shoes won't be enough - I need wellies - anyone know where I might buy some near Clontarf - do Tesco's sell wellies?

@johndodwyer @NWCI the brain and behaviour are inextricably linked you cannot separate them - I believe that you are saying the same thing as me - through engagement of our frontal lobes and higher order functions we can override our more basic 'unthinking' brain functions

@johndodwyer @NWCI the brain uses heuristics to function at a fundamental level but has the capacity for more refined & nuanced thinking to override labelling when it goes beyond its functional purpose to prejudice etc - I think people forget that labels are shorthand but not the totality

@johndodwyer @NWCI It is complex. How would you propose that we move away from labels to a society that treats all humans equally - is there not a need to identify where inequalities exist - and that in turn requires us to use some means of identification i.e. a label

@LunchtimeLiveNT @DrPhilCork @ciarakellydoc Get your flu vaccine. Last December my adult son got sepsis after contracting influenza - thankfully we got him to hospital in time to get Tamilfu but doctors in the hospital said that it was the fact that he had already got the flu vaccine that saved his life #FluVaccine

@johndodwyer @NWCI again I agree I have a particular passion for human rights for older people & people living with dementia. Most people are oblivious that the human rights of older people are regularly violated in Ireland & simply accept age apartheid & disease segregation but thats another story

@johndodwyer @NWCI I understand that - human rights are my guiding principles & I believe more progress could be made through that commonality However, my point here is that he believes that women are currently treated equally to men in Ireland.

Interesting read The 6 presidential candidates talk feminism Which one says 'No, I’m not a feminist and I don’t discriminate by favouring males or females. I would like to think we’re past this as a society and women are treated equally in Ireland.' https://t.co/ASYQYQH2VP @NWCI
@qualann @Conorpope @AAMembership I find this practice hugely annoying also - it happens with internet, TV, electricity etc etc - special deals for new customers - surely they should reward loyalty

@MaryMcAuliffe4 totally agree - at a parent teacher meeting a teacher told me they teach the students morals - when I asked whose morals she looked at me perplexed & said you know morals like don't have sex before marriage! She had no understanding at all that these were catholic morals!!
@Donal_OKeeffe you've a great way with words yourself @Donal_OKeeffe - wouldn't you think the candidates would have put a bit of effort into preparing something meaningful and succinct to say
@dreddiemurphy horrific ageism - with age comes wisdom and experience
